content.description:
Follow the corner to the roof and surmount it into the continuing right-leaning, thin crack and the crux. When the difficulty eases, continue in the same right-leaning crack system to the top.

This was established ground-up onsight.
content.protection:
Standard rack with plenty of small nuts.

Gear anchor. Walk off left.
content.location:
The base of the cliff can be characterized as having two tiers. The upper, left-hand, tier is the launch pad for

Sample Collector

and all pitches left of it. Western Web is the first route, as you move right, that starts from the lower tier. Youre aiming for the obvious, right-leaning corner that ends at a small roof. There is an opposing, left-facing corner that arches in to create the same roof (alternate start). We started in the Y-shaped crack, directly below the opposing pair of corners, and traversed into the right-facing corner.

content.description:
Right of

The Last Daze Of Pompeii

, find an obvious, right-facing dihedral that ends at a roof 25' up. Gain this dihedral, negotiating the fallen dead tree however you like, and surmount the roof at a splitter little finger crack. At the horizontal crack (10' above the roof), move left to the right-leaning crack system. Follow this system for 25 to where you could step right on a small ledge to join the

Apocalyptic Lightning Storm

. This is where the ground-up FA was forced to exit. But the originally envisioned, and eventually completed, line goes straight up. At this point, eschew the tempting ledge out right, and head straight up to a very shallow, right-facing flake which, after a couple cruxy moves, leads to a horizontal crack with good gear. Move 6' left on this horizontal to another vertical crack that peters out and leaves you with a couple sets of perplexing moves to get to the anchor.

On the proud ground-up effort, Nate bailed right into

Apocalyptic Lightning Storm

. Only after toprope rehearsal did I successfully lead the originally envisioned line on 8-9-08. So, this line could certainly be considered a headpoint.
content.protection:
Standard rack, including RPs and offset nuts, up to hand-sized cams. The key piece before the crux runout was an offset nut (brassie) for me.

Two-bolt lower-off anchor.
content.location:
To the right of

The Last Daze Of Pompeii

is a right-facing corner capped by a small roof  25 off the ground. The start is somewhat guarded by a fallen dead tree.

content.description:
Just right of the largest of the big pines growing close to the cliff, climb the steep crack (crux) over the bulge and cross the ledge to a steepening, right-facing corner. Follow it to an overlap, pop up and left out of it, then follow cracks up to the obvious, splitter, thin handcrack in the headwall above. Using this crack, and the one left of it, jam to the top. A small tree a bit back from the edge can be used as a belay anchor.

This was established ground-up onsight.
content.protection:
Standard rack.

Tree anchor, walk off left.
content.location:
To the right of the start for

Apocalyptic

is the furthest right, and largest, of a series of trees growing up close to the cliff. Ring Of Fire starts just right of this tree at a steep crack leading up over a bulge to a large ledge.

content.description:
Take the left-leaning crack through the steep wall right of the starts for

Ring Of Fire

and

Choking Orangey

. Cross the big terrace below the orange headwall and climb the crack system on the headwall's right side. Just right of

Choking Orangey's

splitter.
content.protection:
Standard rack up to big hands size cams.

Tree anchor, walk off left.
content.location: The furthest right pitch on the crag. Start just right of Choking Orangey's initial corners in a steep left leaning crack system.

content.description:
Start in the lower of two rectangular recesses near the base of the left side of the cliff. Move up and right into the higher one and pull out its right side into the shallow, right-facing dihedral. Follow the corner as it arches out right, then cast off onto the beautiful face above, passing two bolts, before reaching a left-facing flake system that leads to the top. Traverse right a few feet to the two-bolt lower off anchor on top of

Last Daze Of Pompeii

.

Established by a top-rope session, bolts placed on rappel, then redpointed.
content.protection:
Standard rack up to hand sized cams. Two bolts.

Bolted lower-off anchor.
content.location: On the left side of the crag there are two left-leaning cracks that emerge from a pair of rectangular recesses near the base of the cliff. The meat of this pitch busts out right from the right-hand of those recesses and climbs the shiny face to the right of the cracks.

content.description: This has good varied crack climbing with a funky roof at the bottom, a bunch of hand-jamming, and a cruxy wide spot 2/3 of the way up. It was established onsight freesolo.
content.protection: Standard rack up to big hands-sized cams. Make a gear anchor on top, walk off left.
content.location: On the left side of the crag there are two left-angling splitters emerging from a pair of rectangular recesses down low. This is the right-hand line pulling out the left side of the higher, right-hand recess.

climbs.name: Last Daze Of Pompeii
climbs.fa: Jason Seaver, Nate Arganbright, Bronson MacDonald,  5/19/07

content.description:
This is a superb, thin crack pitch and the testpiece of the crag. With full knowledge of the potential bias of first ascentionists, I suggest this is one of the best single pitches of thin crack-work on Lumpy Ridge.

At the base of the left side of the crag, there are two rectangular recesses. Just right of these features find a shallow, left-facing corner. Follow this corner, and cracks angling left, up to the orange overlap. Move right under the overlap then launch up into the right-angling, thin crack above. At the first horizontal crack, move left to a short crack, take it to another horizontal, move left again and make one more set of moves to the two-bolt lower-off anchor.

After several falls on ground-up efforts, we resorted to a toprope session. Nate and I both succeeded on redpoint attempts on the next visit.
content.protection:
Standard rack, with plenty of small stoppers, and cams up to hand-sized.

Two-bolt lower off anchor.
content.location: Start down and right of the rectangular recesses at the bottom of the left side of the cliff, at a shallow left-facing dihedral.

climbs.name: The Last Caress
climbs.fa: Nate Arganbright, Edward Corder, Jason Seaver, 4/22/07

content.description:
Climb the left-leaning thin crack / seam with a tenuous and tricky-to protect crux in the first 25.

This was established yo-yo style, ground up.
content.protection: Light rack including RPs and cams up to 2". Gear anchor at top; walk off left.
content.location:
This is the furthest left route on the crag, the thin crack/seam just left of the two obvious, left-leaning splitters (

Chop em Down

and

Nates Solo

).

content.description: This route has excellent crack climbing, hands and locker fingers, with the crux halfway up. It was established onsight freesolo.
content.protection:
Standard rack up to big hand size cams.

Gear or tree anchor on top.
content.location: On the left end of the crag there are two left-leaning, splitter cracks that emerge from a rectangular alcove / roof. This is the left-hand one. Walk off left.

climbs.name: Choking Orangey
climbs.fa: Edward Corder, Nate Arganbright, Jason Seaver, 4/22/07

content.description:
Climb the corner (pair of opposing corners really) and follow the slightly chossy groove above. This leads to a large ledge / terrace underneath the orange headwall, at the top of the cliff, that faces more West than the rest of the crag. Take the obvious, steep, left-leaning splitter through the headwall to the top. Use the same tree anchor as for

Ring Of Fire

.

This was established ground-up onsight.
content.protection:
Standard rack up to one fist-sized cam.

Tree anchor, walk off left.
content.location:
Start this pitch just right of

Ring Of Fire

, on the right side of the cliff, in the obvious, main groove / corner.

content.description:
From the lower tier of ground at the base of the cliff, start behind the middle of a few big pines growing close to the cliff. Follow a series of cracks more or less straight up at first, passing a couple bushes, then angling left to cross

Western Web

. A short thin-hand crack takes you from

Western Web

to a small ledge. From its right side, climb a slim, left-facing corner to a small overlap and, above it, take the left-leaning, thin-hands splitter to the top and a two-bolt lower off anchor.

Established ground-up onsight.
content.protection:
Standard rack with a few extra thin hands-sized cams.

Two-bolt lower-off anchor.
content.location:
This line starts 15 feet right of

Western Web

, crosses it midway up the cliff, and finishes at the same anchor as

Sample Collector

. Start behind one of the big trees at the base of the cliff on its lower tier.
